body: I would be happy to do the external reading and write this description + references. Where should this description be committed?

This seems to be a larger documentation project. Perhaps we can start with a shared [hackmd](https://hackmd.io) document for easy collaboration. When it's finished we can add it to our website and selected parts to the tutorial notebooks? Having another blog post about it may also be useful. What do you think @TonyBagnall?

agreed, let´s try to use this to align on what precisely is the "desired goal" of the documentation project(s). Might be worthwhile discussing also in the context of #354.

E.g., what kind of documentation - besides API reference of course - would be most useful to users and community members?

Also, what is the "end state" of documentation and curation, and associated roles, e.g., a dedicated community role for documentation?
The contribution is really helpful, thanks. I'm not too sure about wider docs, I think Markus and Franz have a better take on it

>I think documentation summarizing the types of classification algorithms and detailed documentation explaining how each of the algorithms work would be really useful.

Agreed - I would find the same useful for *all the components* (transformers of various kinds, reducers, compositors). I have a somewhat encyclopaedic vision of a register of components and composites, with different tags and taxonomies:
* scientific type (e.g., ts classifier, forecaster, transformer of specific type such as series-to-series)
* algorithm type (e.g., neural network, distance-based, etc)
* version/implementation, owner/maintainer and such

I thought the explanation of how individual algorithms work should be accompanied by a tagged register of all of them, and an explanation of the different kinds of algorithm there are (forecaster, classifier, etc) - like in a library.
Couldn't convince the British Library (where the Turing institute is located) to do this, but I still think it would be enormously useful (not just for time series algorithms).

What are your ideas around what kind of documentation would be useful, @lynnssi?

We were also going to discuss somtime soon on a more strategic level where our documentation should move to, and what to prioritize. Would you be interested to participate in such a discussion?

> What are your ideas around what kind of documentation would be useful, @lynnssi?
Possible types of documentation:
- High-level documentation: types of classification algorithms, reduction, etc
- How each algorithm works 
- Examples and tutorials -- especially showing how everything works together
 
> We were also going to discuss somtime soon on a more strategic level where our documentation should move to, and what to prioritize. Would you be interested to participate in such a discussion?

I would be interested in this discussion.
Here's a good graph for explaining dictionary-based algorithms: https://pyts.readthedocs.io/en/stable/auto_examples/approximation/plot_sax.html

>I would be interested in this discussion.

sometime early/mid august probably? Please leave Markus with an email message and we´ll coordinate (need to have a quick internal connect).
Anyone else interested in this issue or contributing to docs, please do the same.

issue.title: [DOC] User guide

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
contributors: @fkiraly, @lynnssi, @mloning

## Purpose of the user guide
In addition to our API reference, we want to create a user guide. The API reference serves as a technical software reference. The user guide should serve as a scientific reference. In the user guide, we want to give an overview of sktime, including the 
* taxonomy of learning tasks, 
* how they are related and the concept of reduction, 
* sktime's package structure, 
* an overview of task-specific submodules (classification, forecasting, etc),
* guidance/explanations of algorithms 

## How to contribute

* All user guide pages are in the `sktime/docs/source/user_guide/` folder, the overview page is `sktime/docs/source/user_guide.rst`
* You can edit existing pages or create new ones and link them in the overview page
* You can use restructured text (`.rst`) format or Jupyter notebooks

## Contents 

### Introduction
"Introduction to SKTIME, motivation, structure, high-level how to use"

* assumption about users: basic understanding of scikit-learn/tabular setting
* introductory example showing that there are multiple learning tasks in a time series context
* "there are many dedicated time series algorithms, you don't have to use deep learning to solve time series problems"

### Overview of time series learning tasks

* task diagnosis (flow diagram): "how to diagnose which task you are dealing with" - include tasks that we currently do not support, see #210
* reduction: how to adapt an algorithm for one task to solve another related task (diagram of reduction relations between learning tasks/algorithms)
* three aspects of task specification: 1) generative setting, 2) learning, 3) evaluation

### Time series transformations
* many time series specific algorithms are compositions of prior transformations and tabular algorithms from scikit-learn
* series-to-series, series-to-primitive 
* variations: fitted to single series or across independent instances
* compositor: apply transforms locally (e.g. on interval) or globally over entire time series

### Time series classification
"predicting a categorical target variable from time series"
* why do we distinguish between time series and tabular regression? 
* example (data generators)
* specifying the task:
    * assumed generative settings (data format: univariate, multivariate, panel data; statistical dependency structure)
    * learning (input/output of algorithm type)
    * evaluation
* variations (univariate, multivariate, online learning)
* algorithm taxonomy: see #355 
    * dictionary-based 
    * frequency-based (e.g. RISE)
    * interval-based (e.g. TSF)
    * shapelet-based
    * distance-based
    * deep-learning
* guidance on algorithm choice 

### Time series regression
"predicting a continuous target variables from time series"
* why do we distinguish between time series and tabular regression? 
* example
* assumed generative settings (data format: univariate, multivariate, panel data; statistical dependency structure)
* learning (input/output of algorithm type)
* evaluation

### Time series clustering

### Forecasting
"temporal forward prediction"
* example
* assumed generative settings (data format: univariate, multivariate, panel data; statistical dependency structure)
* learning (input/output of algorithm type)
* evaluation

### Time series annotation
"annotating time points"
e.g. anomaly detection/outlier detection
* example
* assumed generative settings (data format: univariate, multivariate, panel data; statistical dependency structure)
* learning (input/output of algorithm type)
* evaluation

## Useful resources
* interesting blog post and PyCon presentation about how to structure documentation: https://documentation.divio.com
* sphinx online editor: https://livesphinx.herokuapp.com
* Jupyter books: https://jupyterbook.org/intro.html

body: Hi @lynnssi, we think it's probably best to create a new user guide in which we give an overview of sktime and explain the different modules and algorithms. I've created an issue here for more details: #361. What do you think?
